title: Logitech Superlight 2 vs Razer Viper V3 Pro
metaTitle: Logitech Superlight 2 vs Razer Viper V3 Pro Comparison | Stack Pick
metaDescription: Logitech G Pro X Superlight 2 vs Razer Viper V3 Pro ‚Äî which is the best wireless gaming mouse for UK gamers? Full comparison with UK pricing.
ogTitle: Superlight 2 vs Viper V3 Pro: Best Wireless Gaming Mouse? | Stack Pick
ogDescription: The two best wireless gaming mice go head to head. We break down weight, sensor, battery, and shape to help you decide.
intro: Two of the best wireless gaming mice ever made. Both cost similar money, both use flagship sensors, both are used by pro players. This comparison exists to help you decide which one to actually buy.

productA.name: Logitech G Pro X Superlight 2
productA.desc: Right-hand symmetrical. LIGHTFORCE switches. HERO 2 sensor. 60g. 95hr battery.

productB.name: Razer Viper V3 Pro
productB.desc: Ambidextrous. Focus Pro 35K sensor. 54g. 4000Hz capable. 95hr battery.

sections.heading: Weight ‚Äî Viper V3 Pro wins
sections.body: The Viper V3 Pro at 54g is genuinely lighter than the Superlight 2 at 60g. In isolation both are ultralight, but if you're specifically chasing the lowest possible weight, Razer wins here. Neither mouse will fatigue your wrist on a full day of gaming.

sections.heading: Sensor ‚Äî Both are flawless, Viper edges on paper
sections.body: The HERO 2 in the Superlight 2 and the Focus Pro 35K in the Viper V3 Pro are both objectively flawless sensors ‚Äî zero acceleration, zero jitter, perfectly linear tracking at any speed. The Focus Pro has a higher max DPI (35K vs 32K) and supports 4000Hz polling with the HyperPolling dongle. In practice, at the DPI ranges anyone actually uses (400‚Äì3200), you will not feel a difference. Both sensors are used by top-ranked competitive players.

sections.heading: Polling Rate ‚Äî Viper V3 Pro wins on paper
sections.body: The Viper V3 Pro supports 4000Hz polling with Razer's HyperPolling dongle (sold separately). The Superlight 2 ships at 1000Hz and supports 2000Hz with Logitech's separate adapter. Higher polling means more position updates per second, which reduces input lag. The difference between 1000Hz and 4000Hz is measurable in microseconds ‚Äî real in theory, imperceptible in practice for all but the highest-level pros. If you're not playing at the absolute top of the ladder, 1000Hz is perfectly fine.

sections.heading: Shape ‚Äî comes down to your hand
sections.body: This is the most important factor and it's personal. The Superlight 2 is a right-hand-only symmetrical shape ‚Äî similar to the G Pro Wireless that many pro players have used for years. It suits medium-to-large hands with a claw or fingertip grip. The Viper V3 Pro is ambidextrous ‚Äî it works for both hands and suits a wider range of grip styles and hand sizes. If you're left-handed, Viper is your only option here. If you've used a G Pro before and loved it, Superlight 2 is the natural upgrade.

sections.heading: Battery Life ‚Äî identical
sections.body: Both claim approximately 95 hours of battery life at 1000Hz. Real-world use matches this closely. Neither mouse will need charging more than once a week for most gamers. Both charge via USB-C.

sections.heading: Clicks and switches
sections.body: The Superlight 2 uses Logitech's LIGHTFORCE optical-mechanical hybrid switches ‚Äî essentially optical speed with mechanical feel. They have a satisfying tactile click and are rated for 100M actuations. The Viper V3 Pro uses Razer's Gen-3 optical switches ‚Äî true optical, no debounce delay, also rated for 100M actuations. Both are excellent. The Superlight 2 feels slightly more premium to the touch; the Viper feels crisper and faster.

sections.heading: Software
sections.body: Logitech G HUB vs Razer Synapse. Both have had stability issues over the years. G HUB has improved significantly. Synapse is more feature-rich but heavier. If you're already using one ecosystem's products, stay there ‚Äî mixing is a headache.

buyA.heading: Buy the Superlight 2 if you:
points: Use a right-hand grip (claw or fingertip)
Prefer the G Pro shape that pros have used for years

buyB.heading: Buy the Viper V3 Pro if you:
points: Want the absolute lightest mouse (54g vs 60g)

verdict:
If you're right-handed and have no strong shape preference, the Superlight 2 is our pick ‚Äî the LIGHTFORCE switches are the best clicks we've felt on a wireless mouse and the HERO 2 sensor is proven across thousands of pro hours. It's the safer recommendation for most people.

If you're left-handed, use a palm grip on larger hands, or are coming from a Razer setup, the Viper V3 Pro is the right call. It's lighter, cheaper, and just as capable at any polling rate you'll realistically use.

You genuinely cannot go wrong with either. Both are endgame mice.

title: ASUS PG27AQDP vs PG32UCDM
metaTitle: ASUS PG27AQDP vs PG32UCDM Monitor Comparison | Stack Pick
metaDescription: ASUS ROG Swift PG27AQDP vs PG32UCDM ‚Äî 1440p OLED vs 4K OLED. Which premium gaming monitor should UK gamers buy? Full comparison.
ogTitle: ASUS PG27AQDP vs PG32UCDM: Which OLED Monitor? | Stack Pick
ogDescription: ASUS ROG Swift OLED head to head ‚Äî 1440p 240Hz vs 4K 144Hz. Resolution vs refresh rate. Full UK pricing comparison.
intro: Two of ASUS ROG's finest OLED monitors facing off. The PG27AQDP gives you 1440p at a blistering 240Hz. The PG32UCDM gives you 4K at a more measured 144Hz. Both use OLED panels. Both cost serious money. The question is whether you're a competitive gamer chasing frames or a visual quality hunter chasing resolution.

productA.name: ASUS ROG Swift PG27AQDP
productA.desc: 27" 1440p WOLED, 240Hz, 0.03ms. The competitive gaming OLED ‚Äî maximum frames, minimum input lag.

productB.name: ASUS ROG Swift PG32UCDM
productB.desc: 32" 4K QD-OLED, 144Hz, USB-C 90W. The premium content creation and cinematic gaming OLED.

sections.heading: Resolution ‚Äî PG32UCDM wins, but 1440p is no slouch
sections.body: 4K at 32" is genuinely sharper and more immersive, especially for single-player games, content creation, and anything cinematic. 1440p at 27" still looks excellent ‚Äî the pixel density is high enough that individual pixels are invisible at normal desk distances. For pure competitive gaming, extra resolution adds GPU load without adding competitive value.

sections.heading: Refresh Rate ‚Äî PG27AQDP wins for competitive play
sections.body: 240Hz vs 144Hz is a real difference in competitive gaming contexts. More frames means more current information about enemy positions, smoother tracking, and lower perceived input lag. If you play Valorant, CS2, or Apex at a high level, 240Hz matters. For single-player games, the difference between 144Hz and 240Hz is largely imperceptible.

sections.heading: Panel technology ‚Äî QD-OLED has the edge on colour
sections.body: The PG32UCDM uses QD-OLED (Quantum Dot OLED) which produces wider colour coverage and slightly brighter whites than the WOLED in the PG27AQDP. Both eliminate local dimming completely and produce true blacks. For colour-critical work, QD-OLED wins. For gaming, the difference is subtle.

sections.heading: GPU requirements
sections.body: Running 4K at 144Hz requires significantly more GPU power than 1440p at 240Hz. If you're on an RTX 4070 or below, the PG27AQDP will let you actually use the refresh rate. The PG32UCDM at 4K will bottleneck anything below an RTX 4080 in demanding titles.

buySection.heading: Which Monitor Is Right For You?

buyA.heading: Buy the PG27AQDP if you:
points: Play competitive FPS games (CS2, Valorant, Apex)
Have a mid-range GPU (RTX 4070 or similar)

buyB.heading: Buy the PG32UCDM if you:
points: Play mostly single-player or cinematic games
Do content creation or colour-sensitive work
Have a powerful GPU (RTX 4080 or above)

verdict: For pure gaming performance, the PG27AQDP is the smarter buy ‚Äî it's cheaper, has a higher refresh rate, and pairs with a wider range of GPUs. For the best overall screen ‚Äî gaming, content creation, and cinematic experience ‚Äî the PG32UCDM is exceptional but demands both a high-end GPU and a bigger budget.

title: Logitech G Pro X 2 vs HyperX Alloy Origins
metaTitle: Logitech G Pro X 2 vs HyperX Alloy Origins TKL Comparison | Stack Pick
metaDescription: Logitech G Pro X 2 LIGHTSPEED vs HyperX Alloy Origins TKL ‚Äî wireless premium vs wired value. Which TKL keyboard should UK gamers buy?
ogTitle: G Pro X 2 vs HyperX Alloy Origins: Best TKL Keyboard? | Stack Pick
ogDescription: Wireless premium vs wired value ‚Äî two of the best TKL keyboards for competitive gaming compared for UK gamers.
intro: The G Pro X 2 is one of the most acclaimed wireless TKL keyboards ever made. The HyperX Alloy Origins TKL is a full-aluminium wired TKL that costs almost half the price. Both target competitive gamers. The question is whether wireless is worth the premium.

productA.name: Logitech G Pro X 2 LIGHTSPEED TKL
productA.desc: LIGHTSPEED wireless, GX switches, aluminium top, 2000Hz polling. Best wireless TKL.

productB.name: HyperX Alloy Origins TKL
productB.desc: Full aluminium body, HyperX Red switches, USB passthrough, detachable cable. Outstanding value.

sections.heading: Wireless vs Wired ‚Äî the core trade-off
sections.body: LIGHTSPEED wireless is legitimately comparable to wired ‚Äî Logitech has proven this across years of pro adoption. You will not notice input lag. What you will notice is the freedom of no cable and the need to charge every ~50 hours. The Alloy Origins is wired but adds a USB passthrough port, which is actually useful on a desk where USB ports are occupied.

sections.heading: Build quality ‚Äî Alloy Origins has more aluminium
sections.body: Both are built for competitive use. The Alloy Origins has a full aluminium body which is slightly more premium in terms of raw material. The G Pro X 2 has an aluminium top plate with a plastic base to save weight. Both feel solid and will survive competitive use. The Alloy Origins is noticeably heavier.

sections.heading: Polling rate ‚Äî G Pro X 2 has a meaningful edge
sections.body: 2000Hz polling on the G Pro X 2 means double the position updates per second compared to the standard 1000Hz on the Alloy Origins. This is a real difference at the highest competitive levels. For most gamers at sub-Radiant / sub-FACEIT Level 10, 1000Hz is perfectly adequate.

sections.heading: Switches ‚Äî both are solid linear options
sections.body: GX Red and HyperX Red are both smooth linear switches suited to gaming. The GX Red has a slightly lighter actuation force. Neither requires switch comparison to be the deciding factor ‚Äî both will perform well in competitive use.

buyA.heading: Buy the G Pro X 2 if you:
points: Wireless is a priority for you

buyB.heading: Buy the HyperX Alloy Origins TKL if you:
points: Want the best build quality per pound spent
Want to save ~¬£75 for peripherals elsewhere

verdict: The G Pro X 2 is the right choice specifically if wireless is your priority. LIGHTSPEED is genuinely excellent and if you're cable-averse, the premium is justified. Outside of that use case, the Alloy Origins is the smarter buy.

title: Secretlab Titan Evo vs Herman Miller Aeron
metaTitle: Secretlab Titan Evo vs Herman Miller Aeron Comparison | Stack Pick
metaDescription: Secretlab Titan Evo 2022 vs Herman Miller Aeron ‚Äî gaming chair vs office chair. Which is better for long gaming sessions? Full UK comparison.
ogTitle: Secretlab Titan Evo vs Herman Miller Aeron: Gaming vs Office Chair? | Stack Pick
ogDescription: The best gaming chair vs the best office chair ‚Äî which one should UK gamers actually sit in for long sessions?
intro: This is the comparison that gets asked most often in gaming communities: should I buy a proper gaming chair, or spend the money on an office chair? The Secretlab Titan Evo is the best gaming chair. The Herman Miller Aeron is the gold standard office chair. Here's an honest answer.

productA.name: Secretlab Titan Evo 2022
productA.desc: Magnetic head pillow, 4-way lumbar, cold-cure foam. The gaming chair built like a proper product.

productB.name: Herman Miller Aeron (Remastered)
productB.desc: 8Z mesh, PostureFit SL, 12-year warranty. For daily 7+ hour seated work and gaming.

sections.heading: Ergonomics ‚Äî Herman Miller wins clearly
sections.body: The Aeron was designed by Bill Stumpf after studying human posture for years. The PostureFit SL supports both the sacrum and lumbar simultaneously, which no gaming chair pillow system replicates. The 8Z mesh zones provide varying tension across the back. If you sit for 8+ hours per day, the Aeron will outperform any gaming chair for long-term back health.

sections.heading: Comfort for gaming specifically
sections.body: Gaming chairs generally recline further (the Titan Evo goes to 165¬∞), which is useful for leaning back during casual play. The Aeron is designed for upright working posture and has limited recline. For pure gaming comfort with controller in hand, gaming chairs win. For competitive mouse-and-keyboard gaming where you sit upright, the Aeron's ergonomics make it the better choice.

sections.heading: Build quality and longevity
sections.body: Herman Miller's 12-year warranty reflects the Aeron's build quality. These chairs routinely last 15‚Äì20 years. Secretlab's Titan Evo has improved significantly over its predecessors and the cold-cure foam holds its shape better than budget gaming chairs, but gaming chair materials (especially leatherette) degrade faster than mesh. The Aeron is a long-term investment; the Titan Evo is an excellent mid-term gaming purchase.

sections.heading: Value
sections.body: At ~¬£399, the Titan Evo is the best gaming chair you can buy at that price. At ~¬£1,100, the Aeron is a significant investment but amortised over 15 years is ¬£73/year. If you work from home full-time or game 6+ hours per day, the Aeron pays for itself in back health. If you game 2‚Äì3 hours casually per evening, the Titan Evo is the rational choice.

buySection.heading: Which Chair Is Right For You?

buyA.heading: Buy the Titan Evo if you:
points: Want recline and a headrest included
Don't work from home all day

buyB.heading: Buy the Herman Miller Aeron if you:
points: Sit for 6‚Äì10 hours per day (work + gaming)
Have existing or past back problems
Want a chair that lasts 15+ years
Work from home and need true ergonomics

verdict: Buy the Titan Evo if you're a gamer who games. Buy the Herman Miller Aeron if you sit at a desk most of the day and game on top of that. The Aeron is the better chair ‚Äî but the Titan Evo is the better gaming chair at its price point.

title: SteelSeries Arctis Nova Pro vs Sony INZONE H9
metaTitle: SteelSeries Arctis Nova Pro vs Sony INZONE H9 | Stack Pick
metaDescription: SteelSeries Arctis Nova Pro Wireless vs Sony INZONE H9 ‚Äî which premium wireless gaming headset is right for UK gamers? Full comparison with UK pricing.
ogTitle: Arctis Nova Pro vs Sony INZONE H9: Best Premium Wireless Headset? | Stack Pick
ogDescription: SteelSeries Arctis Nova Pro Wireless vs Sony INZONE H9 ‚Äî two of the best wireless gaming headsets go head to head.
intro: Two premium wireless gaming headsets competing for the same buyer ‚Äî someone who wants the best wireless audio for gaming without compromise. The Nova Pro has been a community favourite for years. The Sony INZONE H9 brings PlayStation integration and Sony's audio pedigree. Here's how they compare.

productA.name: SteelSeries Arctis Nova Pro Wireless
productA.desc: Hot-swap battery system, dual-source connectivity (PC + console simultaneously), ANC. The Swiss army knife of gaming headsets.

productB.name: Sony INZONE H9
productB.desc: 360 Spatial Sound for PS5, best-in-class ANC for a gaming headset, 32-hour battery. Ideal PlayStation ecosystem headset.

sections.heading: Battery system ‚Äî Nova Pro wins completely
sections.body: The Nova Pro's hot-swap battery system is genuinely unique. You get two batteries ‚Äî one in the headset, one charging in the base station. When one dies, you swap in under 10 seconds. Effectively infinite battery life. The Sony H9 has 32 hours which is good, but you will eventually have a dead headset at an inconvenient moment. For serious gaming, the Nova Pro's system is a meaningful advantage.

sections.heading: ANC ‚Äî Sony H9 wins
sections.body: Sony's noise cancellation technology is best-in-class even on their consumer headphones. The INZONE H9 carries this over ‚Äî its ANC is noticeably stronger than the Nova Pro's. If you're in a noisy environment (shared flat, open office, family home), the H9 will block more sound.

sections.heading: PS5 integration ‚Äî INZONE H9 wins decisively
sections.body: The Sony INZONE H9 connects directly to PS5 via USB and enables 360 Spatial Sound ‚Äî Sony's full 3D audio implementation that takes advantage of the PS5's Tempest Engine. This is the headset Sony designed for their own console. The Nova Pro works with PS5 but doesn't get the same deep integration.

sections.heading: Dual device connectivity ‚Äî Nova Pro wins
sections.body: The Nova Pro connects to PC via 2.4GHz dongle and a console via optical simultaneously, with instant audio mixing between both sources. You can hear Discord on PC and game audio from PS5 at the same time. No other headset at this price does this as seamlessly.

sections.heading: Sound quality for gaming
sections.body: Both are excellent for gaming audio. The Nova Pro has a slightly flatter, more neutral tuning which is better for competitive play (footstep detection). The Sony H9 has a warmer, more bass-heavy profile that many gamers prefer for immersive single-player experiences. Neither is objectively better ‚Äî they suit different preferences.

buyA.heading: Buy the Arctis Nova Pro if you:
points: Use PC as your primary platform
Want the best competitive gaming audio tuning

buyB.heading: Buy the Sony INZONE H9 if you:
points: Want the best ANC in a gaming headset

verdict: If you're a PC-primary gamer or a multi-platform gamer who uses PC and console simultaneously, the Nova Pro is the better headset ‚Äî the hot-swap battery and dual-source connectivity are genuinely class-leading features. If you're primarily on PS5 and want the best integration and strongest ANC, the Sony INZONE H9 at ~¬£90 less is the smarter buy.
